Thanks for the tip on green tea - I'll ask my oc nurse today.  May 23, 2008 11:19 pm, edited May 24, 2008 06:05 AM by rockrock wrote:Chemotherapy Tips I'd been collecting pointers from this thread and others which my friend Miki graciously compiled/organized for me, and I have tried to update along the way. As with all things chemo, everyone is different. What works for one person (or one therapy), may not work for everyone. My "chemo bag" Ask them to put together a small make-up type bag (say 4"x4"x6" or smaller) that you can move from purse to backpack back to purse or whatever that includes some of the stuff that's good to have on hand when you're out and about: digital thermometer, Tylenol, toothbrush, toothpaste, Breathsaver-type lozenges, chapstick, unscented hand lotion, eye drops, antibiotic ointment, Purell sanitizer or handwipes, Saltines or animal crax, Kleenex, thin cap to ward off any sudden chills. And maybe a maxi-pad in case of any port or drain mishaps. (Why this stuff? Important to ward off mouth sores, avoid fever/monitor temp, chemo dries out eyes, mouth, skin; lack of nose hairs causes drippy nose.) Pre-Chemo/Things to ask about • What sort of antiemtics (anti-nausea meds) are you getting? According to American Society of Clinical Oncology guidelines, everyone should be getting Emend (for nausea), a steroid (dexamethasone aka decadron is the most common), and a medication like Kytril or Zofran (the Aloxi you may get in your IV at chemo is in the same family of drugs). Drugs like phenergan and compazine are NOT considered sufficient but might be used in addition to the others. Possible side-effects A description of the functions and side effects of common chemotherapy drugs is available at www.chemocare.com. General care • Drink a lot of fluid, preferably water. • For moisturizers, you probably want something as scent free as possible (e.g., Aquaphor is recommended). • If you get a manicure or pedicure, bring your own manicure set To keep your overall health up • Make laughing and relaxing as important as cleaning! • Support your immune system with iron- and protein-rich foods (but check with doctor before taking supplement) • Careful with protein bars (or any other foods) that contain soy if you are ER+ • Closing the toilet seat before flushing will dramatically reduce distribution of bacteria in the bathroom. • Replace the shower curtain liners. • Get soft, seam-free (or as seam-free as possible) hat for sleeping-in • Wear latex-gloves when cleaning to avoid nicks and scratches Metallic taste • Use plastic flatware instead of metal • Biotene mouth wash (and/or toothpaste and chewing gum, lemon/lime cordial, Breathsavers mints) • Oasis products were also mentioned Mouth sores • "If you get mouth sores, there's a little cocktail you can whip up with liquid benadryl and Maalox." • I put lemon or lime drops or slices into my water glass - • Someone recommended Vitamin C supplements but my dietitian said "No Vitamin C supplements for women with breast cancer EVER." (I posted her explanation elsewhere.) • Change your toothbrush frequently • Eating a popsicle or ice chips or something else very cold, while being given adriamycin Hairy tongue * Frequent cleansing with combo of water, baking soda and salt is recommended, * Sucking on lemon wedges to re-encourage salivary glands, * Brushing one's tongue with a toothbrush, hydrating with water. Cytoxan seems to mess with the salivary glands. Port care • The nurse may clean the port by injecting Heperin into it. A horrible taste can sometimes be avoided by holding your nose while the Heperin is injected. • A numbing agent may make entry in and out of the port less painful.* Pain/aches • Specifically if you are going to be getting Neulasta, Aleve was recommended as a pain killer for aches. The poster suggested taking one 30 minutes prior to the Neulasta injection, and then regularly for 2-3 days after. • Tylenol is the first pain killer of choice as it has the fewest possible side-effects (I was told "No Ibuprofen or aspirin.") Sleeplessness • Ambien CR • I'm nervous about "sleep aids" so the nurse recommended I take a Benadryl. Acid reflux/indigestion • An H2 blocker such as Pepcid or Nexium Constipation • Prune juice • Colace (docusate sodium) is an over the counter stool softener to have on hand. • Senekot-S is a gentle laxative with a little Colace added in. • Eating active culture yogurts (e.g., Activia) is recommended by some • Snacking on things like prunes or dried apricots can help • Lots of water helps here, too. • A square of chocolate ExLax the night of chemo, and another one the following evening. Then gallons of water and tea. Eat Activia yogurt every single day. The secret, the poster suggests, may be taking taking something at the same time as the chemo before things can get really bottled up, so to speak. • A cup of coffee when I"m in caffeine withdrawal seems to help! • Avocadoes (eaten straight out of the skin, w/ a little salt, pepper, & olive oil) are helping me out! Diarrhea • Imodium is good for stopping this • Key worry is dehydration, so keep drinking water! • Stay away from sugary things, as refined sugar can aggravate diarrhea • From a dietary perspective, you can try the BRAT diet: Banana, Rice, Applesauce, Toast, which is often very helpful. • One recipe offered: o 1 Green Plantain (not banana) Usually Spanish stores or grocery have o 1 garlic clove o Olive oil o Boil the plantain and add a pinch of salt; mash it and add garlic and olive oil (note from Miki, I'd be very cautious about how much olive oil). "Nether Region" Care • Another tip - keep a squirt bottle by the toilet and rinse your self off with warm water after urinating for the first week or so. The chemo often burns on the way out, causing discomfort. An old water bottle or ketchup bottle. If soreness is still a problem, take Uristat or AZO - both over the counter. These are analgesics which help with the burning and pain. But remember to have yourself checked out if you have bladder symptoms, because lowered bloodcounts can lead to bladder infections. • If you wind up with diarrhea, I strongly recommend the flushable moist wipes; they really help with general soft tissue irritation. • The first few days after chemo, I use moist wipes to try to prevent discomfort. Hair loss (A/C around 14-19 days after first chemo) • Hair net! • You may want to get a silk or satin (very soft/smooth) pillowcase for when your hair begins to fall out; scalp may be sensitive. • I got my long hair cut short pre-chemo. No clue how to style short hair. My "stylist" said my I should style my new short hair with the tips of the fingers applied to the tips of the hair (rather than my hands). • When hair starts to fall, a lint roller helps to remove lingering hairs. Food. Here is a link for Summer Express: 101 meals to be prepared in 10 minutes or less. http://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/18/dining/18mini.html?_r=1&scp=10&sq=100+recipes&st=nyt&oref=slogin

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2009 06:10AM rinna40 wrote: Well Ladies. I think I'm the first June Chemo recipient. I started yesterday. I went first to get my pic line in - had to wait over and hour.  Then down to oncology, saw my nurse and my oc, and despite my incision openning up on saturday, and leaking out about  cup full of old blood, and still dripping a bit, I was given the go ahead.  I have to say that the nurses/staff were wonderfull, most people were upbeat. I even went out for dinner last night becuase I didn't feel so bad. I did start getting nauseous at about nine at night. I'm on ondansetron (SP?) for nausia, and I take it every 12 hours. I took one at about 10 pm, went to bed. It wasn't the best sleep. I'm afraid to lay on my left breast for fear of leakage and now my right arm has the pic line and it was a little sore. I woke many times feeling a little sick, but fell back to sleep within ten to 15 minutes. I was feeling ok this morning. My DH helped get the kids ready for school, but I was good enough for the five minute walk to the bus stop!! I't is now 9 am and I still have an hour to go before my next pill, but I feel OK. I had some PB&J on toast for breakfast, and am drinking some green tea with ginger ( ginger is supposed to settle the stomach). So far not too bad. I need to start a regimine for rinsing my mouth. I was told to rinse about four times a day to help stop sores. All and all, I think the worst part of last night was waiting for sickness to start. I'll see what today brings. Sending positive calming vibes to all!!!! Rinna

Then my DH took the family out for dinner, and we looked at a boat we are considering buying. Now that is something I don't know if we should do. It is a little on the expensive side for us, and I hope I'm not being foolish and giving myself and expensive 'treat' in the midst of all this. Hmmmmm Hair: Well, I'm day seven out of tx2 and I STILL HAVE STUBBLE!  I agree that it makes the wig uncomfortable, and it looks like crap. You can't see my gray ones too much, but the dark ones still look like by DH's five o'clock shadow. But I do love my wig. I've had people who don't know me too well compliment my new haircut. That brings me to another question - body hair. Should I go there? My arms still have what seems like a normal amount of hair. I've still had to shave my legs (although only once in the last three weeks). Eyebrows and lashes still in tight. Even some pesky chin hairs holding strong. Does anyone know when these will fall? I'm happy if the brows never fall, but I don't want to be too hopeful. Mouth sores: I've been drinking water with lemon wedges. Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2009 06:16PM rinna40 wrote: Mary: I had a picc line put in on June 1st. They gave me a gauze type 'sleeve' to slip over it to hold the dangly bits in, although I don't find it works too well. The nurses have also wrapped it with gauze, but I find that stretches during the day and slips off as well. I went on line and googled picc line covers and found a site that sells covers. They are sort of stretchy material that slips over it. They also sell water proof covers for the shower.I ordered a couple, about 40 dollars for the two, but have not received them yet. With regards to showering, I was told to wrap the picc line in saran wrap or some other some other plastic and definitely not get it wet. I tried the saran wrap and it didn't work for me. I also have a friend (who is quite thin) and she cut off the finger part of a surgical glove and used the wrist part to cover the picc line. Unfortunately for me, my arms are a little too thick for this, but it worked well for her. Hope this helps. Rinna

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2009 10:53AM rinna40 wrote: I had a seroma after my lumpectomy and node dissection. The seroma should be absorbed into the tissue and resolve itself, and many surgeons don't mind a small seroma, because it helps keep the shape of the breast while the tissue grows in and fills the void. However, I had complications, the seroma grew too big, and forced the incision open. That happened to me at the end of march, I had to have a second surgery to close it, (resulting in some disfigurement) and it opened again with the same thing. I went through six rounds of chemo with an open wound. I am now on what's called VAC therapy, as the wound is still not completely closed, and am waiting for this to finally heal before starting rads.  All that being said, my surgeon and a second surgeon both say that my situation is not normal. My only warning would be to watch it carfully. They can get a ultrasound doctor (don't know the correct term)  to drain it if it swells too much. I wish I had been more proactive when my swelling started. Good luck to you.

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2009 11:31PM rinna40 wrote: I too had a seroma (not sure of the size) after a re-excision to get clean margins. I told my surgeon about a sloshing sound in my breast. He (and another surgeon I later went to for 2nd opinion) told me that it is sometimes a good thing to have some fluid because it helps the breast keep it's shape. He didn't drain it. About two weeks later my incision opened, and at least a litre of dark red fluid came out, and my breast was deflated. I had about 6 weeks of homecare packing the wound (ordered by my oncologist, not the surgeon who sent me home with some gauze and tape lol). At that point my family doctor advised that I do a secondary close, as it was nowhere near healed, and I was waiting to begin chemo and rads.Two weeks after that surgery (during which I lost about 20% of my breast) the incision opened again. I started chemo the next day, and had an open wound throughout all of chemo. I've now been out of chemo two months, and the incision is finally closed, and I will finally start rads on monday.  Long story I know, but after the second close I got two more opinions, and it seems that seromas usually resolve themselves. No doctor can predict which way they go. I could spend a lot of time being angry that my surgeries had complications, that my breast isn't as pretty as it was after my first lumpectomhy, but  that won't get me anywhere. Now, that surgeon also did a hernia operation on my with no complications. That being said, I didn't like his post op care and felt he could have shown more concern for my situation. I wouldn't go to him again. But I don't believe he committed malpractice.   I know it is frustrating to think - if he had only listened to me. I felt like that for a long time too. After some research I've come to realize that no surgery is without risks and sometimes things happen that are out of our control Good luck to you, and let us know what you decide.

Posts.Title: Scared!! Janina Mazy1959

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2009 04:12PM rinna40 wrote: RBurton: I too had severe bone and joint pain while on Docetaxol.  I finished chemo on Sept. 14, and still have lingering aches - very minor. I keep thinking that I'm about to come down with H1N1, as I did not think the aches could still be related to the chemo. Now I am sure that they are, as I have no other symptoms of being ill. Do you know how long these aches can last? As I said, they are very minor, so I don't want to get medication, just would like them to go away.  I also had severe watering eyes. I too could not wear make up - very distressing when you don't have eyelashes, so your eyes already looked washed out. For me, that SE has almost disappeared. I wasn't informed of this as being a SE, and my family doctor kept insisting that it was seasonal allergies. I knew that it wasn't as I have had seasonal allergies and this was different. My eyes did not feel irritated at all, but the water works would not stop. It is soo frustrating when people think that you are crying. Sunglasses were my best friend. My hugs to your wife. Perhaps you can tell her that about two months out these SE's are all but gone for me. I hope the same happens for her.
Posts.Title: Side effects: Muscle and Joint Pain, Watery irritated eyes. RBurton RBurton

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2010 09:08PM rinna40 wrote: I've actually enjoyed being on a leave. I'v had the chance to spend more time with my young children. I've started working out more regularly. I cook better meals for my family. My last challenge is our back basement. I want it organized before I go back full time in March. I agree. Pick some goals and you'll feel good about the time off.
